entry.title: Re: Consignment Stock Update is not updated based on Ship to Customer in MSKU
entry.content: That sounds like a tricky limitation. Tracking consignment stock only at the sold-to level definitely reduces visibility, especially when you’re managing multiple ship-to locations. Have you looked into any custom enhancements or user exits that might allow tracking at the ship-to level? Would be great if SAP provided a standard solution for this scenario—it’s a pretty common requirement.

entry.title: Ordem de venda considerando preço errado
entry.content:
Olá especialistas,

Estou com um cenário que acredito que possam ajudar

Ao criar uma Ordem de Cliente pela transação VA01, o preço do material está sendo considerado automaticamente em dólar


Quando o processo correto seria considerar o preço em BRL que está cadastrado na hierarquia do cliente pela transação VK12

 

Conseguiriam ajudar em relação a essa divergência? Onde posso verificar porque está puxando o valor em dólar?

Agradeço o apoio!

entry.title: Re: Effective way of doing an UPDATE with INNER JOIN in A...
entry.content:
With ABAP 7.50, you don't have much choice, so I would say that your solution is the easiest one, but I would select only the required columns of TABLE2 to reduce the size of the internal table:

TYPES BEGIN OF ty_data.
INCLUDE TYPE table1 AS table1.
TYPES table2_short_id TYPE table2-short_id.
TYPES END OF ty_data.

DATA lt_data TYPE TABLE OF ty_data.
DATA lt_table1 TYPE TABLE OF table1.

SELECT table1~*, table2~short_id
      INTO TABLE _data
      FROM table1
      INNER JOIN table2 ON
          table1~field1 = table2~field1
      WHERE table1~field2 IS NOT NULL.

LOOP AT lt_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_data>).
  <fs_data>-table1-short_id = <fs_data>-table2_short_id.
  INSERT <fs_data>-table1 INTO TABLE lt_table1.
ENDLOOP.

MODIFY table1 FROM TABLE lt_table1.

Another solution is to create an updatable database view with the two tables joined, with only the concerned columns (key fields and column to update) and directly update this view in ABAP. The only problem is that you can't define a view with WHERE IS NOT NULL.

A third solution, if your database is SAP HANA and you want a better performance, is to define an AMDP procedure to update via native HANA SQL (UPDATE table1 SET ... FROM ... JOIN ... WHERE ...)

NB: you may also use other native SQL solutions (ADBC, EXEC SQL), I prefer AMDP because it's best suited for organizing the code.

entry.title: Re: TEMSE management - Getting error in Background Job
entry.content:
According to SAP notes, another possible reason is about intermittent network errors.

Also:

1510259 - Syslog message F3V 'Error XXX for write/read access to a file. File = <filename>' - SAP for Me

3492363 - "Error reading job log" (BT167) in random batch jobs - SAP for Me and 3157443 - How to detect a "Ghost" Instance - SAP for Me

entry.title: Using Self-Sovereign Identity and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection
entry.content:
In the fast-evolving semiconductor industry, understanding market demand is both critical and challenging. Modern data spaces—secure, collaborative environments where multiple organizations share data—offer new opportunities for more targeted and privacy-preserving demand collection. One innovative approach combines Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and verifiable credential (VC) vouchers to streamline questionnaire management within these data spaces, balancing control, security, and participant autonomy.Scenario Overview

Imagine a data space consisting of several semiconductor manufacturers, suppliers, and customers who share and analyze market-relevant data. A central operator is responsible for orchestrating activities such as conducting demand questionnaires. When a new demand questionnaire is to be launched, the operator:

  1. Creates the Questionnaire: The operator designs the survey and defines eligibility criteria.
  2. Selects Participants: A selected set of companies are chosen to respond, based on criteria such as region, company type, or previous participation.
  3. Issues Vouchers: For access control and tracking, the operator generates individual questionnaire vouchers, implemented as verifiable credentials (VCs).
  4. Delivers Vouchers: Each selected participant receives their unique VC voucher in their SSI wallet.
  5. Participant submits survey and uses voucher

Participants wishing to respond must not only submit the completed questionnaire but also cryptographically prove their eligibility and participation using their questionnaire voucher.

Let's break down how this system works from a technical perspective.

Implementing Questionnaire Vouchers with Self-Sovereign Identity

  1. Questionnaire Creation and Participant Selection
    1. The central operator, with authority in the data space, defines the questionnaire’s structure and the set of questions to be asked.
    2. The operator identifies a list of eligible participants (e.g., certain manufacturers or suppliers).
  2. Issuing Personalized Questionnaire Vouchers
    1. For each selected participant, the operator creates a Questionnaire Voucher VC. This digital VC attests that the holder is invited to respond to a specific questionnaire.
    2. This voucher VC may include metadata such as: Questionnaire ID, Expiry date, Participant’s organizational identifier (may be pseudonymous), Operator’s signature and issuance timestamp. The voucher VC is cryptographically signed by the operator, serving as the issuer.
  3. Distributing Vouchers via SSI Wallets
    1. Each participant has an SSI wallet—a secure application or service capable of receiving, storing, and presenting VCs.
    2. The central operator pushes the individual voucher VC to each participant’s SSI wallet, typically via secure data space messaging protocols (like DCP).
  4. Participant Submission Process: When a participant is ready to respond, the process is as follows: Identification & Eligibility Demonstration: The participant identifies with the questionnaire portal using a verifiable presentation (VP) including the  Questionnaire Voucher VC. This proves to the operator that the submission is uniquely authorized for this questionnaire and prevents duplicate or unauthorized submissions.
  5. Response Submission: The participant fills in and submits the questionnaire through the portal, attaching the required VPs. The operator’s backend verifies the voucher, ensuring only authorized participants’ responses are accepted and counted. The operator revokes the voucher VC so that it can be used only once.

 

Example Setup Guide: SSI and Questionnaire Vouchers for Demand Collection

The following guide outlines the steps for using SSI components for a demo of demand collection using Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and questionnaire voucher verifiable credentials (VCs) in a simulated semiconductor demand forecast environment.

The scenario involves an Operator—the trusted orchestrator—and a Participants—organization invited to respond to a new market demand questionnaire.

Technical Stack

This demo spotlights the core Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) workflow for secure questionnaire access using SAP’s Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV). The example abstracts away the questionnaire application itself, focusing purely on the exchange and verification of Verifiable Credentials (VCs). The operator uses DIV to issue VCs (Membership and Questionnaire Voucher) and verify credential presentations. Each participant uses an DIV tenant to: Receive and store VCs and create verifiable presentations (VPs).

Step 0: Prerequisites

Before creating a DIV tenant, ensure that:

  • If you have not yet subscribed, go to the SAP Partner Portal and subscribe to the TDD license: SAP Partner Portal - TDD License. Once subscribed, you get an DIV entitlement. In a second step the provisioning can be triggered from SAP for Me. Therefore you need a S-User with admin rights.
  • You have the necessary administrative permissions in SAP BTP to create tenants.

... more information

Step 1: Environment Preparation – Create DIV Tenants

Operator Tenant Setup

Set up a DIV tenant for the operator with both protocol roles: „dcp-holder“ and „dcp-issuer“.

POST {provisioning_service}/api/v1.0.0/operations

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



{

    "entity": "customer-wallet",

    "action": "provision",

    "payload":{

        "customerName": "operator",

        "customerId": "0",

        "divWalletServiceName" : "main",

        "divWalletServiceParameters": {

            "applications":[{

                "application": "sc",

                "description": "sc",

                "companies": [

                    {

                        "name": "operator",

                        "protocols" : ["dcp-holder", "dcp-issuer"]

                    }

                ]

            }

            ]

        }

    }

}

 

Publish Credential Schema

Define and publish the schemas for the required credential type (Voucher).

POST {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/jsonSchemas
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application": "sc",
  "payload": {
    "schema": {
      "jsonSchema": {
        "$id": "https://example.com/schemas/voucher-credential-schema-V2.json",
        "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
        "title": "SC Voucher",
        "description": "SC Voucher to submit a questionnaire",
        "type": "object",
        "properties": {
          "credentialSubject": {
            "type": "object",
            "properties": {
              "id": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "name": {
                "type": "string"
              },              
              "voucherId": {
                "type": "string"
              },
              "questionnaire": {
                "type": "string"
              }            
            },
            "required": [
              "id",
              "voucherId"
            ]
          }
        }
      }
    },
    "name": "SC Voucher",
    "description": "SC Voucher"
  }
}

Configure Issuer Settings

In the operator tenant, configure the issuer to specify which credential types (voucher) it can issue, selecting the published schemas for each type.

### Get DID

GET {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



### Get Issuer Configuration

GET {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{id}/issuerConfigurations

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



### Extend Issuer Configuration

PATCH {div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/companyIdentities/{id}/issuerConfigurations/{id}

Content-Type: application/json

Authorization: Bearer {token}



{

  "addCredentialTypes": [

  {

    "name": "voucher",

    "approvalMode": "last_vc",

    "schema": "{link to schema}"

  }]

}

 

Register Operators DID as a Trusted Issuer

To ensure the validity and trustworthiness of the issued Verifiable Credentials (VCs), it is necessary to register the issuer as a trusted issuer within the system. Only credentials issued by entities on the trusted issuer list will be recognized and accepted; this prevents the acceptance of credentials from unknown or unverified sources.

 

 

### Add issuer to trust list
POST {{div_srv}/api/v2.0.0/trustLists
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "sc",
    "payload": {
      "name": "Operator",
      "did": "{operator DID}",
      "ignoreMissingHashlist": false,
      "credentialTypeConfiguration": [
        {
        "credentialType": "voucher",
        "autoAcceptOffers": true
        }
      ] 
    }
}

Participant Tenant Setup

For each participant, set up a DIV tenant with the protocol role: „dcp-holder“ (to receive and hold VCs and create presentations). Participants do not require issuer capabilities or schema configuration—only the ability to receive credentials and generate verifiable presentations.

### Provision DIV Wallet
#  operation_req
POST {provisioning_srv}/api/v1.0.0/operations
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "entity": "customer-wallet",
    "action": "provision",
    "payload":{
        "customerName": "Participant 1",
        "customerId": "1",
        "divWalletServiceName" : "main",
        "divWalletServiceParameters": {
            "applications":[{
                "application": "sc",
                "description": "sc",
                "companies": [
                    {
                        "name": "Participant 1",
                        "protocols" : ["dcp-holder"]
                    }
                ],
                "trustedIssuers": [{
                    "name" : "operator",
                    "did" : "{operator_did}",
                    "credentialTypeConfiguration": [
                        {
                        "credentialType": "voucher",
                        "autoAcceptOffers": true
                        }
                    ]
                }]
            }]
        }
    }
}

 

Step 2: Issue and Offer Verifiable Credentials

The operator is responsible for generating vouchers credentials for the participants. Once created, these credentials will be issued and offered directly to the participants. The process ensures that each participant receives a unique voucher credential, which can be later used to submit the demand questionnaire.

 

 

### Create voucher VC
POST {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
    "application": "sc",
    "payload": {
        "issueWithSignature": {
            "content" : {
                "@context": [
                    "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
                    "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
                ],
                "name": "Voucher for Participant 1",
                "description": "Demand submission voucher",
                "expirationDate": "2027-02-10T16:51:22.000Z",
                "type": [
                    "voucher"
                ],
                "issuer": "{Issuer DID}",
                "credentialSubject": {
                    "id": "{Holder DID}",
                    "name": "Participant 1",
                    "voucherId": "1234",
                    "questionnaire": "Demand 2026"
                },
                "credentialStatus": {
                    "id": "{revocation list}",
                    "type": "StatusList2021"
                },
                "credentialSchema": {
                    "id": "{schema link}",
                    "type": "JsonSchema"
                }
            },
            "signature" : {
                "proofMechanism" : "external", 
                "proofType" : "jwt"
            }
        }
    }
}

### Offer VC to Participant
POST {div_ srv}/api/v2.0.0/dcp/credentialOffers/send
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "credentials": [
    "{vc id}"
  ]
}

 

Step 3: Participant Presents VCs for Questionnaire Submission

Participant presents the required voucher VC as a verifiable presentation (VP). Therefore the participant has to create a verifiable presentation including the VC.

 

### Get Credentials
GET {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/credentials
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

### Create VP
POST {div _srv}/api/v2.0.0/presentations
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application": "sc",
  "payload": {
    "prove": {
      "@context": [
        "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/v1",
        "https://www.w3.org/2018/credentials/examples/v1"
      ],
      "type": [
        "QuestionnairePresentation"
      ],
      "holder": "{Participants DID}",
      "proofFormat": "jwt",
      "verifiableCredential": [
        {
          "jwt": "{Membership VC as JWT}"
        },
        {
          "jwt": "{Voucher VC as JWT}"
        }             
      ],
      "aud": "{Operator DID}"
    }
  }
}

 

Step 4: Operator Verifies the Verifiable Presentation

The participant submits a Verifiable Presentation (VP) to the operator. The operator then validates the included Verifiable Credential (voucher) by performing the following checks: verifying that each VC has not been revoked, confirming that each VC was issued by a trusted issuer, ensuring that all VCs are still within their validity period (not expired), and validating the cryptographic signature on the presentation. Only if all these checks are successfully passed is the VP accepted.

 

### Verify VP
POST {div_ srv}/api/v2.0.0/presentations/
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {token}

{
  "application" : "sc",
  "payload" : {
    "verify" : {
      "presentation" : "{presentation}"
    }
  }
}

 

Step 5: Operator Revokes Used Voucher

After a voucher is used, its associated verifiable credential is immediately revoked. This revocation ensures that the credential cannot be verified successfully a second time, thus preventing reuse or fraudulent redemption attempts.

PATCH {{div_wallet_srv}}/api/v2.0.0/credentials/{{vc.response.body.data.0.id}}
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{get_xsuaa_token.response.body.access_token}}

{
    "payload" : {
        "revoke" : true
    }
}

Conclusion

By leveraging the power of Self-Sovereign Identity and verifiable credentials, questionnaire-driven demand collection in semiconductor data spaces becomes both secure and flexible. The voucher-based approach ensures invitations can’t be spoofed or misused, and that only intended participants contribute to strategic market analyses. As data sharing ecosystems mature, patterns like these will be crucial for trustworthy, privacy-preserving collaboration across industry boundaries.

 

References

  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Dataspaces
  • SAP help: Documentation of the DIV Provisioning Service
  • API documentation

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP Warehouse Management with Quality Management – Full Process Flow
entry.content:
Why WM-QM Integration in SAP?

In SAP, integrating Warehouse Management (WM) with Quality Management (QM) ensures seamless coordination between logistics and quality control during material movements. When materials arrive in the warehouse, they often need to undergo quality inspection before being released for use or sale.

Without Integration:

  • Inspection lots are handled separately from warehouse stock
  • Manual tracking is required for inspection samples and blocked stock
  • Risk of errors and delays in material availability increases

With WM-QM Integration:

  • Inspection stock is automatically directed to quality bins in the warehouse.
  • Transfer Orders (TOs) are created and confirmed in sync with inspection results.
  • Warehouse and quality teams work in a unified, automated process, improving accuracy, compliance, and efficiency

Conclusion: Materials flow through the warehouse with built-in quality checks, ensuring only approved stock is put away for consumption or delivery.

SAP WM - QM Integration: Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Define Inspection Sample Model

Path: SPRO > Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Define Inspection Sample Control

Key Settings:

  • QM Control Indicator: Determines where the inspection sample is managed (sample bin, GR area, warehouse, or skipped).
  • Inspection Bin: Manual or strategy-based bin for storing inspection samples.
  • Sample Handling: Determines how inspection samples are processed.
  • Rounding Option: Round off samples to full pallet if needed.

Step 2: Assign Quality Control Indicator to Storage Type Search

Path: Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Activate QM Interim Storage Type Search

This links the Quality Control Indicator with the Storage Type Search, allowing the system to identify the correct storage type during GR.

Step 3: Define Storage Type Search

Path: SPRO > Logistics Execution > Warehouse Management > Interfaces > Define Quality Management > Define Storage Type Search (As Necessary)

Purpose: Determines to which storage type a material should be moved during putaway, using the Storage Type Indicator.

Step 4: Create Product/Material Master (App: Manage Product Master/Create Material)

Actions:

  1. Ensure Quality Management view is maintained.
  2. Activate Post to Inspection Stock
  3. Example: Material WMQMTSTMAT created with relevant QM and WM views

 

Quality Management view in Material Master

Step 5: Create Purchase Order (App: Manage Purchase Orders/ME21N)

Details:

  1. PO created with QM relevant material
  2. Due to QM activation, stock will automatically be posted to Quality Inspection stock during GR.

Step 6: Post Goods Receipt (App: Post Goods Movement/MIGO)

System Behaviour:

  1. Stock moves to Inspection Stock at IM Level
  2. Warehouse stock is placed in GR zone/interim storage bin

Stock Overview at IM Level

Stock Overview at WM Level

Step 7: Convert Transfer requirement to Transfer Order (LT06/LT04)

Purpose: Trigger warehouse movement by converting the TR into a TO.

Step 8: Confirm the Transfer Order (App: LT12)

Action: TO confirmation moves stock to quality inspection bin in warehouse

Stock Movement at WM level

Step 9: Perform Quality Inspection (App: QA32)

Tasks:

  1. Inspect the Material
  2. Make the usage decision
  3. System moves the stock from inspection to unrestricted (based on usage decision)

Check stock at IM level

Since stock transfer happened, in warehouse posting change notice has been created.

Display TO

Step 10: Confirm Post-Inspection TO (App: LT12)

Action: Confirm the TO created by the system when the stock is released from QI.

Stock now available in unrestricted stock at WM level

Step 11: Perform Bin-Bin Transfer (App: LT10)

Action: Optional movement of stock from one bin to another (within the warehouse)

Check stock at WM level

If you found this guide helpful, don’t miss my other SAP MM blogs covering real-world automation, configuration tips, and best practices for procurement and inventory management.

Click to view other SAP MM WM Blogs - SAP Community

 

Regards,

Leelamohan

entry.title: Re: ATP rule selection in Collective ATP check on COHVPI
entry.content:
How COHV / COHVPI decides which Rule to use is system reads Order Type → finds OPJK settings. Checks whether the order is still unreleased or already released. If the corresponding flag is set, it applies the same Checking Rule you’d get in COR1/COR2. The material’s Checking Group (OVZ2/OVZ3) and this Checking Rule together define the scope (stocks, receipts, issues) of the ATP check.

When you run a mass material availability check in COHV (Mass Processing: Production Orders) or COHVPI (Mass Processing: Process Orders), the system does not use a new, special rule. It simply picks up the same check logic you’ve defined for individual orders; either for planned orders or for process orders—based on your SPRO customizing.

Generally you don’t use COHV for pure planned orders, but if you do a check in a custom mass process, the logic is the same as CO40. Check in SPRO Production Planning → Detailed Scheduling → Global Availability Check → Maintain Check Mode, Maintain Check Instructions (assign PP event). Only “Product availability check” and “Check against forecast” functions apply to planned orders.

The below table will give you an idea about Process Orders (Released & Unreleased)

entry.title: Re: Influencing posting price at GR with BAPI_GOODSMVT_CR...
entry.content:
Dear Lakshmipathi, dear Dominik,

thank you for your feedback.
I think the EXBWR parameter works as described in note 3546987, at least when I am checking our movements in the system with MvT 292 or 561.
My intention initially was to influence the price in a GR movement with MvT 101 with  ref to a PO with account assignment F (refurbishment order). 
I think this most probably is covered by question 6 of note 3546987. 

There is a wider Process - which we don' need to discuss here - but at least that you know the root cause of may request.
We are using the refurbishment process with subcontracting, but we do not have split valuated materials, which somehow is a prerequisite for this.
In this process there are to goods receipt postings with MvT 101.
One done by the user with transaction MIGO with reference to subcontracting PO, which includes MvT 101 (GR) and MvT 543 (consumtion of subcontracting stock). Since the PO has an account assignment F with reference  to the refurbishment order, it is consumed and the stock level is not correct.
Therefore a second automatic  GR posting is triggered by BADI_DIAD_GOODMVT_1, which adjusts the stock level.

Our problem is now, that since we don't use split valuation for materials, the amount of this two GR postings are added, that partly the refurbished materials are more expensive as new identical materials would be. First GR is valuated with the PO price (refurbishment costs) and the second one with the moving average price of the refurbished material. 

Therefor my intention was to post the second GR like free of charge in oder that the moving average price is not updated with it, but unfortunately this doesn't work.
I think I will try to raise this in a customer influence request, since split valuation is not very common. At least for small and mid sized companies.

Br Heinz

entry.title: Display of the Number of Goals per User in People Analytics Story Reporting
entry.content:
A typical requirement in talent management reporting is to show the number of employees according to the number of goals, i.e. performance goals or development goals. Such a chart could help to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. In this blogpost alternative approaches are presented to realize such a reporting requirement in People Analytics Story Reporting.

Introduction

An important HR requirement in talent management is to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. See left side in Figure 1 which shows

  • Total number of considered employees
  • Total number of Objective plans which is the number of combinations of employees and objective plans (e.g. if one employee has goals in 3 of the selected objective plans, then the number “3” is considered; if an employee has goals in a single objective plan or also in none of the selected objective plans, then the number “1” is considered)
  • Total number of Goals (e.g. if an employee has 3 goals in ‘objective plan A’ and 5 goals in ‘objective plan B’, then the number “8” is considered)
  • Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan, i.e. which is just the “Total number of Goals” divided by the “Total Number of  Objective Plans”

The chart in Figure 1 shows the “Total Number of Objective Plans“ according to the number of goals. You can see that there are 1229 employees which don’t have any goals in one of the selected objective plans, 28 employees with a single goal in the selected objective plans, 11 employees with 2 goals and so on.

 Figure 1   'Histogram' (more precise, 'chart of type "Bar/Column") to show the number of employees per number of goals

Solution Approach

In the following the different steps are explained how to create a query and the respective story to derive the chart as it is shown in Figure 1.

1. Query creation

Create the query as shown in Figure 2. Note that:

  • The object “Primary Objective Fields” from “All Templates” in schema “Objective Management” is used. This was chosen to allow the possibility to select one or multiple bonus plans as indicated in Figure 1 on the right.
  • The anchor of the query is “Basic User Information” from schema “User”. It is also possible to create the query the other way round. However, only when having "Basic User Information" as anchor it is possible to derive also the employees without any goal plans and goals.

Select at least fields like employee name, user ID, objective plan ID, objective plan name and goal. You might add also filters e.g. to consider only goal plans in status “completed”, “on track” but to ignore goal plans in status “Cancelled” or “Postponed”.

Figure 2   Query based on “All Templates” within schema “Objective Management”

2. Story measure calculations

Create the following 4 story calculations as indicated in Figure 3, 4, 5 and 6.

To illustrate the necessity to calculate the “Total Number of Objective Plans” let’s consider the following example: Assume there are 100 employees for “goal plan 2023” and 120 employees for “goal plan 2024”. Further assume you run the report for both bonus plans. Then the number of employees is 120 (under the assumption that the 100 employees of “goal plan 2023” are among the employees relevant for “goal plan 2024”). This is derived with the calculated measure “Employees” as shown in Figure 3. However, more important for our report is the combination of employees and goal plans which is 220 (=100 + 120). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 3   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of employees

Figure 4   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the total number of objective plans

The next calculation is the overall number of “goals”. Let’s stick at the example from above; let’s assume that the 100 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2023” overall 400 goals and that the 120 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2024” overall 590 goals. Here, it could be possible that one goal as e.g. “Improve my leadership skills” is for some of the employees part of “goal plan 2023” as well as part of “goal plan 2024”. Nevertheless, the combination of employees and goal plans is 990 (=400 + 590). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Goals” as shown in Figure 5. To derive the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” it is now just required to divide the “Total number of goals” and “Total Number of Objective Plans”. For the example here, this would be an average number of 4,5 goals (=990 / 220).

Figure 5   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of goals

Figure 6   Story calculation of type ‘Calculated Measure’ to derive the quotient between “Number of Goals” and “Total Number  of Objective Plans”

 3. Story Dimension Calculation

The final calculation step is transforming the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” into a dimension. It is important to consider the “Dimension Context”: Our use case is to show the Number of Goals per Employee and Objective Plan. Therefore, the dimension context is the employee (i.e. the field ‘User ID’) and the goal plan (i.e. ‘objective plan ID’). Here, the bit ‘tricky’ part is to find meaningful ‘goal ranges’ (i.e. ‘Member Name’) so that the visual representation results in a chart that basically resembles a Gaussian distribution (see Figure 7). Furthermore, it is recommended to provide a counter as prefix to the ’Member Name’ (i.e. (1), (2), (3), ….), so that the sorting works properly (if this ‘prefix would be missing, in the sample provided here the sorting would be “1 Goal”, “13-15 Goals”, “16 and More Goals”, “2 Goals”, “3 Goals”, ….).

Figure 7   Story calculation of type ‘Measure-Based Dimension’ to convert the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan”

4. Chart Creation

Finally, it is possible to create a visual presentation of the previously calculated figures. Figure 8 shows a “Bar/Column” chart with the measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” and dimension “Goal Ranges”.

Figure 8   Bar chart with measure ‘Total Number of Objective Plans’ and dimension ‘Goal Ranges’

5. Further remarks:

  • Of course, the presented approach works not only for goals/objective data but also for (1) any similar (e.g. performance form data) or (2) also slightly different use cases (e.g. number of particular benefits rolled out/claimed per employee).
  • Instead of manual definition of “Member Names” as shown in Figure 7 you could also tick “Use measure values as dimension members”. However, in addition to the shortcomings described above (1. no Gaussian distribution; 2. confusing sorting), ‘members’ without any ‘Goals per Employee/Objective Plan’ would not show up in the Bar Chart.
  • It is also possible to use a chart of type “Histogram”. Use “Total Number of Goals” as ‘Measure’ and “User ID” and "Objective Plan ID" as ‘Aggregation Dimension’. Then, you have to adjust the ‘Chart Properties’. It is not recommended to switch off ‘Automatically Set Range of Values’: With this option you would probably generate odd ranges. However, for the use case of goals it is recommended to use fixed ranges as e.g. “14” as “’Number of bins’ and “1” and “15” as ‘Minimum’/’Maximum’ (important: choose 'Number of Bins' plus "1" for the 'Maximum'; only then each range covers the range of "1.00"). As shown in Figure 9 this approach works also fine (compare numbers from Figure 1 with numbers of Figure 9). 
    Advantage: This approach is faster to implement; only "Total Number of Goals" (see Figure 5) needs to be created
    Disadvantage: (a) The case of employees without any goal (see 1st column of 1229 employees/goal plans without any goal defined) is missing and (b) Less flexibility regarding the definition of 'Goal Ranges' (in particular to define something like "More than 16 goals)"
    Therefore, the approach which is previously described is more recommended.

 Figure 9   Chart of type "Histogram" to show the number of goals per employee/objective plan

Should I bring custom parameters like the number of dump rigs needed per product and other sequencing parameters criteria into PPDS, and then enhance the schedule sequence heuristics so planned orders on both packing lines are sequenced based on hopper requirements?
From what I understand, the business sees the shared resource constraint as the main priority, followed by setup optimization.

Thanks

Debasis Nanda

entry.title: Re: Record received for duplicate entity LMS - Integratio...
entry.content: @JA-RA, "Could you please explain how we could filter in the LMS only the most recently used record in onboarding?" - As I understand it, there wouldn't be a way to overcome the "Record received for duplicate entity" scenario from the Learning end in terms of configuration or file reading (KBA 2346506). The adjustment would need to be made on the Integration Center end, when the file is created, which is something you're already tweaking.

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to use MF60 for creating WM transfer r...
entry.content:
Hello @bgmatthews192 

MF60 is used to transfer stock between storage locations, i.e. to a production storage location. I would suggest using WM-PP Interface to supply production within a single LE-WM managed storage location.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: Delete/Bulk Delete User Learning History SF LMS
entry.content: @RachitGupta, currently, there isn’t an option via the application or API that’d allow the Learning history deletion in mass (KBA 2436676). About the APIs, they’re not designed for extracting/deleting/importing high-volume data from or to Learning (KBA 2804267). The Learning Product Management team has accepted this enhancement request. We kindly ask you to monitor it, along with the What's New page, for any potential news, while this is further assessed.

entry.title: Re: Syntactically incompatible change of existing functio...
entry.content:
Based on what OSS note 2215852 describes in the adaption notes, try inserting this block of code (with exception handling added per needs) right before the BAPI call.  I don't have a way to test it, but this is what it suggests to address the issue.

      CALL METHOD cl_matnr_chk_mapper=>bapi_tables_conv_tab
        EXPORTING
          iv_int_to_external       = abap_true
          it_fnames                = VALUE #( ( int  = 'MATERIAL'
                                                long = 'MATERIAL_LONG' ) )
        CHANGING
          ct_matnr                 = lt_delivery
        EXCEPTIONS
          excp_matnr_ne            = 1
          excp_matnr_invalid_input = 2
          OTHERS                   = 3.

      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*       Implement suitable error handling here
      ENDIF.

 

Regards,

Ryan Crosby

entry.title: Employee Central Alerts: Limitation
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

Since SAP SuccessFactors introduced specific rule scenarios for configuring Business Rules, we now have the option to use the "Generate Employee Central Alerts" scenario to trigger alerts in EC.

However, I've encountered a limitation: it is not possible to use personal base objects —specifically, Dependent or Employee Information —within this rule scenario. This restriction prevents us from setting up alerts based on conditions such as "employee turns 65" or "dependent reaches 18 years old."

Has anyone found a workaround for this limitation? 

Thanks in advance for any suggestions!

entry.title: Re: Can IDOCs like "DOCMAS" format can be used to upload...
entry.content:
Hello @DEEPU92 

Yes, DOCMAS IDocs can be used to transfer DMS metadata (like document number, type, status) between SAP systems using IDOC_INPUT_DOCMAS.

However, DOCMAS does not transfer original files. To include file content, use:

  • IDOC_INPUT_DOCUMENT_LOAD, or
  • BAPIs like BAPI_DOCUMENT_CHECKIN2

So, use DOCMAS for metadata, and handle file transfer separately if needed.

Best regards

Reference Documentation:

SAP Help on DOCMAS IDoc Structure

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How to identify Business Catalogs for OAuth
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

How to identify the Business Catalog for an OAuth 2.0 configuration?

 

Kind regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to identify Business Catalogs for OAuth
entry.content:
Hello, 

 

When you set up a communication arrangement using OAuth, you can click OAuth 2.0 Details, select the scope and click Granted by Business Catalogs to find the necessary details. The relevant catalogs will be displayed. This way you can retrieve the business catalogs that are required for calling the service. For more information check SAP Help Portal | How to Create Communication Systems.

For specific APIs, I kindly ask you to reach out to the application component responsible for the API. 

 

Kind regards.

entry.title: How to create the Picking WT via PPF based on the Planned delivery date?
entry.content:
Dear All,

We would like to explore the possibility of configuring Warehouse Task creation based on the Planned Delivery Date instead of the current logic.

This adjustment would help align the picking list generated from condition records more closely with actual delivery planning, improving both operational efficiency and planning accuracy. Could you please advise on how this can be implemented within the existing system framework?

Looking forward to your guidance.

entry.title: In Freight Pricing Condition what is the difference between the "Account" and "Accrual"
entry.content: It was my understanding that in OBYC you set up in "Account" column should post to the freight expense account and the TRNx set up in the "Accrual" column would post to the Freight clearing account.  These postings I thought would occur during a Goods Receipt.  What really happens with the GR is that it posts to whatever TRNx is aligned in the "Accrual" column.  GR seems to completely ignore the "Account" column

entry.content:
Hello,

While performing the Proof of Delivery (POD) process, I attempted to raise an OVER exception. For example, I posted a Goods Receipt (GR) for 4 pieces, but I wanted to use the OVER exception to adjust it to 5 pieces.

However, the system is displaying an error message stating that only 4 pieces are available, which prevents me from processing the OVER exception.

Could you please advise what might be causing this issue and how I can successfully apply the OVER exception in this scenario?

entry.title: Request for Information About Getting a SAP License for Academic Teaching
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am a university lecturer at the Faculty of Economics and Management in Sfax (Tunisia), and I am in charge of teaching the course Enterprise Resource Planning Systems to students in business and computer science.

As part of this course, I would like to introduce SAP as a practical tool to help students become familiar with a real-world ERP system.

I sent two requests for Educational License of SAP Software for Academic Use (to sapnextgen@sap.com and webmaster@sap.com) on behalf of my university six days ago (on July 30, 2025), but I have not received any response until today.

In addition, I also accessed the Academic Alliances website and clicked on the "Contact us to become a member" button. I filled out the form to request an Educational License of SAP Software for Academic Use on behalf of my university, but I have not received any reply either.

Is there anyone who can help me obtain this license, especially since the academic year is starting soon and I need the SAP tool for my practical sessions?

Best regards

entry.title: Issue Granting Access to Users Imported from Starter System to IAS
entry.content:
Dear team,

We are currently facing difficulties granting access to the users that were created in the Starter System and later imported into Identity Authentication Service (IAS).

As shown in the attached screenshot, the users do appear in the system under the “Maintain Business Users” app. However, they are still not able to log in despite the User Name is the Same in the IAS. as in the Business User created un the Starter System. Also the roles were assinged to the Business Users before exporting them to the IAS.

Could you please help us understand what might be missing?

In particular, does the column labeled “Connected” have any impact on whether the users can access the system? Only System Administartor user appears as “Yes” in that field, while the others show no value.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Oscar Quijano

entry.title: Re: How to integrate an Adyen terminal into SAP Customer Checkout
entry.content:
I've tried performing all the steps stated on the guide (including also the ones of the GitHub repo), but at the moment of trying to proceed with the payment it gives us a "Connection Reset Error". I've tried by disabling the Firewall of the computer where the Customer Checkout is being run, and also by using a different internet connection. The payment terminal has the last update and curiously tried to see if it was an issue of the terminal by using a Mock program offered by Adyen to test payments and in that case it worked detecting the terminal and all that. The issue is between the connection of the CCO, the computer and the payment terminal.

Hope somebody here can provide some guidance of what could be the actual cause of the issue and how to solve it (if it's something to modify of the CCO installation or settings, the computer itself or from Adyen platform).

Master Data in article , PO and SO seems OK nevertheless is clear that we had a mismatch combination between our POs and theirs SOs.

POs were received partially and we do not expect more deliveries coming. We did try to Block at PO item level and/ or populate Latest GR Date however the POs (and POs items) still appearing in reports as "S" or mark as "delete item".

Message error is self explanatory but wondering if there is an ALTERNATIVE option to DCI these POs apart from all reverse process (invoices are already created) which involves a few people and time consuming.     

Invalid season year 2025, season XX, collection Q1 and theme combination

Message no. FSH_MSG_CL_SEASONS046

entry.title: Need help with SP_TransactionNotification
entry.content:
I have this UDO IVZ_DOC_AT without an audit table.

I need to block all users except 124 from adding or updating tasks.

My script is:

IF ( :object_type = 'IVZ_DOC_AT' AND (:transaction_type = 'A' OR :transaction_type = 'U'))
 
THEN 
cnt :=0;
 
SELECT COUNT ("UserSign") INTO cnt FROM "@IVZ_DOC_AT" WHERE "Code" = :list_of_cols_val_tab_del AND ("UserSign" <> 124) ;
 
If cnt > 0 
Then
error := 994;
error_message := 'Usted no es un usuario autorizado para modificar el Objeto'||' '||cnt;
End if;
 
END IF;
 
The problem is the UDO's UserSign allways is 124 because is the addon's user and that creates all records. 
In case the user wants to create a new doc, the block works ok; otherwise, if the user must update info, the result of the query is cnt = 0 because the UserSign is always 124.
 
How can I proceed with this block in SP_TN?
 
Thank you a lot, and sorry about my English.
 
JP

entry.title: Manage payments for import purchases
entry.content:
Hi everyone.

We need to resolve an import scenario using S4 public cloud.

One shipment contains multiple purchase orders, and we need to issue payments or advances for the entire shipment.
Question: How can we associate multiple purchase orders with a shipment?

On the other hand, we use conditions to plan import expenses paid to different suppliers within purchase orders containing many items. Question: How can we mass update import-related conditions? We need to place the customs agent or freight forwarder inside those conditions?

@Luana_Lovison

entry.title: Re: Post Depreciation on last period only
entry.content: No Just create custom depreciation key. The name is used is Z+75%+12 month posting = Z7512 . I hope this answers your question. 🙂

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition - F0798 "Create Bil...
entry.content:
Dear Ravi,

You can test if this application provides an IAM App of type Display Only.

IAM Apps are entities of applications that are related to one transaction that can relate to several app authorization variants to define different access rights. The different app authorization variants grant access to the same SAP Fiori launchpad content through the transaction.

 Example
The Maintain Business Users app has the Fiori ID F1303 and, for example, the following app authorization variants:

  • an app authorization variant called Display Business Users (IAM app ID: F1303_03_TRAN) with read authorization

  • an app authorization variant called Assign Business Users to Business Roles (IAM app ID: F1303_22_TRAN) with write authorization

  • an app authorization variant called Maintain Business Users (IAM app ID: F1303_TRAN) with write authorization

All three app authorization variants belong to the transaction code F1303. They grant access to the same tiles and target mappings in SAP Fiori launchpad but have separate IAM app IDs with the prefix F1303. If you only want to grant read access to business users assigned to a specific business role, for example, you activate the Display Business Users app authorization variant (F1303_03_TRAN).

 

Go to "IAM Apps" inside your Business Role and check if there's a transaction for this specific app which is Display only. 

 

Kind regards,
Tayane.

entry.title: Re: I_JournalEntryItem”无法在Customer Data Browser”里显示问题-如何在...
entry.content:
Dear Joey, 

 

As per the KBA 3486459 - CDS View or Table is not available in Customer Data Browser app - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in Customer Data Browser, some CDS Views/tables are not enabled to be visualized. Not all the CDS Views/tables are allow-listed by the LoB's to view the data. SAP is working with the LoB's to increase the coverage of the Objects list.

In the case of a CDS View, please create a Custom CDS View using the CDS View as a data source, then it's possible to preview the created Custom CDS View and it will show the data included in the data source.

 

Kind regards,

Tayane.

entry.title: Re: My Inbox App customizing
entry.content:
Dear Erwan,

This behavior is expected because the "My Inbox" application does not currently support UI adaptation.

To make UI adaptations, navigate to the Purchase Order apps and perform the changes there. For further information, refer to the documentation Extensibility for Purchase Order Apps 

 

Kind regards,

Tayane.

You can find all of these informations in the KBA 2758274 How to Manage Permissions in SmartEdit where we gathered the links that explain the necessary permissions, either roles, read and write ones:

entry.title: SAP Adobe Fragment Form - Dynamic content on the master template
entry.content:
I have developed a custom Adobe form (content form) for Purchase Order using a custom Gateway (OData) service in an S/4HANA Private Cloud environment. Alongside, I created a separate master template form, based on the standard SAP SOMU master template (Haven't enhanced the existing OData service of master template).

In the master template, we have maintained the company logo in the header (MST1) and the terms and conditions on page MST2. We are using the “Define Master Template Rule” to pass the logo and footer texts from “Manage Logo” and “Manage Texts,” respectively.

Everything is working well so far, but we’ve encountered a challenge: we need a header section that appears on every page of the content form. However, we cannot define this in the master template because the data needed for this header (e.g., purchase order number, date, customer name, etc.) comes from the custom OData service used only in the content form — and not accessible within the master template.

Since the master template can only access static content like the logo and footer text, how can we implement a header section within the content form that repeats on every page and binds dynamic data from the OData service?

I have refereed to this blog to create the fragment-based form.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/understanding-fragments-based-adobe-form-building-using-livecycle-version/ba-p/13455763

entry.title: Re: Accessing deployed SAP Build Apps app in SAP Public C...
entry.content:
Hi @Filip_Polak 

Thank you for that question. I will walk through some details about Build Apps:

  • Pleae note, SAP Build Apps are deployed to SAP BTP as stand alone HTML5 apps. They are not placed in Work Zone unless you configure them to be.
  • However, you can access them from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via a custom tile in the Launchpad, which opens the app in a new window.
  • Embedding Build Apps directly in the S/4HANA Public Cloud Launchpad shell is not currently supported due to SAP’s content security and clean-core principles.
  • Build Apps is suitable for side-by-side apps, especially when combined with SAP BTP destinations to securely consume S/4HANA APIs.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: subcontracting with rm sold and invoiced
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a case where our company produces flour. We are sub-contracting pasta making to a supplier where he will be using our flour but due to regulation, we have to issue an invoice for the quantity of flour to be used for pasta production.

in SAP, the subcontracting PO process consider transferring the flour to the supplier without issuing any invoice (flour will still be  owned by our company). 

Also, this same supplier is also a customer that is buying flour for his own consumption.

My questions are:

1- how to process a subcontracting PO where part of the BoM (flour) is sold and invoiced? is it possible?

2- in order to differentiate the customer from supplier, we consider creating another BP number for the same customer name but defined as customer and supplier in order to track the sold flour and the purchased finished good (pasta). Does this make sense?

3- From accounting perspective, how should I treat the transactions (POs and invoices, payments...), shoudl I create different GL accounts for the different BP numbers?

Appreciate your help on this

entry.title: Re: where to download SAP wen ide?
entry.content:
Hi @swswswswsws 

Thank you for your question.

SAP Web IDE has been officially retired and replaced by more modern tools like SAP Business Application Studio on SAP BTP. As of recent, SAP no longer offers Web IDE for download or deployment, and it is not legally available via mirrors or third-party sites, as it’s proprietary software.

Note, if your company previously downloaded the personal edition it may still be available under your SAP S-user. You can reach it via https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/software-downloads.html

Note that SAP has removed most Web IDE versions and it's very unlikely you’ll find it unless your account had legacy entitlements. If your project critically depends on  specific SAP Web IDE  you can request for temporary access if it was once licensed under your account. For this you will need to open a ticket with SAP.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Consume SAP Data Warehouse Cloud in Power BI
entry.content:
@thomasrohmann1 I did find a workaround to this... It turns out that database user's can in fact be maintained within a DAC in SAP Datasphere... In your permissions table where you define the authorization values for your Data Access Controls instead of giving the User ID as your email address simply replace this with the Database Users username... You must add the entire user name "SPACE#USER". Then you can just assign authorizations to this DB user as you would a application user.

I hope this makes sense... But please feel free to drop me a private message if you would like additional clarity.

entry.title: Re: Hands-on Tutorial: SAP Databricks
entry.content:
Thank you, @AndreasForster and @stojanm! I was able to complete the main flow (without "Good to know" for now).

In a Basic Trial, the schema `workspace.default` seems to be shared, so I had to give a unique table name `overnightstays_witalij` to avoid authorization issues for the existing (but not visible) `overnightstays` table.

FYI, I tried cloning your git repo https://github.com/SAP-samples/mee-samples.git into the workspace, instead of downloading and uploading individual files. It worked fine with notebooks, but I did not manage to create a table from the CSV file. I still need to look at how to do that 🤓

For the environment, I decided to try using Dependencies -> Added -> Apply, and it worked well:

But I had to include `mlflow`, not just `prophet`, Python packages.

Once again, thank you for sharing this!!
